an6.62:3.1: 62 Knowledge of the Faculties of Persons
an6.62:4.2: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants when he arrived at a town of the Kosalans named Daṇḍakappaka.
an6.62:4.3: The Buddha left the road and sat at the root of a tree on the indicated seat.
an6.62:4.4: The mendicants entered Daṇḍakappaka to look for a guest house.
an6.62:5.1: Then Venerable Ānanda together with several mendicants went to the Aciravati River to bathe.
an6.62:5.2: When he had bathed and come out he stood in one robe drying himself.
an6.62:5.3: Then a certain mendicant went up to Venerable Ānanda,
an6.62:5.5: “Reverend Ānanda, when the Buddha declared that Devadatta was
an6.62:5.6: going to a place of loss, to hell, there to remain for an eon, irredeemable, did he do so after fully deliberating, or was this just a way of speaking?”
an6.62:5.7: “You’re right, reverend, that’s how the Buddha declared it.”
an6.62:6.1: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha,
an6.62:6.2: bowed, sat down to one side,
an6.62:6.3: and told him what had happened.
an6.62:7.1: “Ānanda, that mendicant must be junior, recently gone forth, or else a foolish, incompetent senior mendicant.
an6.62:7.2: How on earth can he take something that I have declared definitively to be ambiguous?
an6.62:7.3: I do not see a single other person I have made a declaration about after giving such full deliberation as Devadatta.
an6.62:7.4: As long as I saw even a fraction of a hair’s tip of goodness in Devadatta
an6.62:7.5: I did not declare that he was
an6.62:7.6: going to a place of loss, to hell, there to remain for an eon, irredeemable.
an6.62:7.7: But when I saw that there was not even a fraction of a hair’s tip of goodness in Devadatta
an6.62:7.9: going to a place of loss, to hell, there to remain for an eon, irredeemable.
an6.62:8.1: Suppose there was a sewer deeper than a man’s height, full to the brim with feces,
an6.62:8.2: and someone was sunk into it below their head.
an6.62:8.3: Then along comes a person who wants to help make them safe, who wants to lift them out of that sewer.
an6.62:8.4: But circling all around the sewer they couldn’t see even a fraction of a hair’s tip on that person that was not smeared with feces.
an6.62:8.5: In the same way, when I saw that there was not even a fraction of a hair’s tip of goodness in Devadatta
an6.62:8.7: going to a place of loss, to hell, there to remain for an eon, irredeemable.
an6.62:8.8: Ānanda, if you’ll listen to the Realized One’s knowledges of the faculties of individuals, I will analyze them.”
an6.62:9.2: Now is the time, Holy One, for the Buddha to analyze the faculties of persons.
an6.62:9.3: The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
an6.62:9.4: “Well then, Ānanda, listen and pay close attention,
an6.62:10.1: “Ānanda, when I’ve comprehended the mind of a person, I understand:
an6.62:10.2: ‘Both wholesome and unwholesome qualities are found in this person.’
an6.62:10.3: After some time I comprehend their mind and understand:
an6.62:10.4: ‘The wholesome qualities of this person have vanished, but the unwholesome qualities are still present.
an6.62:10.5: Nevertheless, their wholesome root is unbroken, and from that the wholesome will appear.
an6.62:10.6: So this person is not liable to decline in the future.’
an6.62:10.7: Suppose some seeds were intact, unspoiled, not weather-damaged, fertile, and well-kept. They’re sown in a well-prepared, productive field.
an6.62:10.8: Wouldn’t you know that those seeds would grow, increase, and mature?”
an6.62:10.10: “In the same way, when I’ve comprehended the mind of a person, I understand …
an6.62:10.15: This person is not liable to decline in the future …
an6.62:10.16: This is how another individual is known to the Realized One by comprehending their mind.
an6.62:10.17: And this is how the Realized One knows a person’s faculties by comprehending their mind.
an6.62:10.18: And this is how the Realized One knows the future origination of a person’s qualities by comprehending their mind.

an6.62:11.8: Wouldn’t you know that those seeds would not grow, increase, and mature?”

an6.62:12.1: When I’ve comprehended the mind of a person, I understand:
an6.62:12.2: ‘Both wholesome and unwholesome qualities are found in this person.’
an6.62:12.3: After some time I comprehend their mind and understand:
an6.62:12.4: ‘This person has not even a fraction of a hair’s tip of goodness. They have exclusively dark, unwholesome qualities. When their body breaks up, after death, they will be reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.’
an6.62:12.5: Suppose some seeds were broken, spoiled, weather-damaged. They’re sown in a well-prepared, productive field.
an6.62:12.6: Wouldn’t you know that those seeds would not grow, increase, and mature?”
an6.62:12.8: “In the same way, when I’ve comprehended the mind of a person, I understand …
an6.62:12.11: ‘This person has not even a fraction of a hair’s tip of goodness. They have exclusively dark, unwholesome qualities. When their body breaks up, after death, they will be reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.’
an6.62:13.1: When he said this, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha:
an6.62:13.2: “Sir, can you describe three other persons who are counterparts of these three?”
an6.62:13.4: “Ānanda, when I’ve comprehended the mind of a person, I understand:
an6.62:13.5: ‘Both wholesome and unwholesome qualities are found in this person.’
an6.62:13.6: After some time I comprehend their mind and understand:
an6.62:13.7: ‘The wholesome qualities of this person have vanished, but the unwholesome qualities are still present.
an6.62:13.8: Nevertheless, their wholesome root is unbroken, but it’s about to be totally destroyed.
an6.62:13.9: So this person is still liable to decline in the future.’
an6.62:13.10: Suppose that there were some burning coals, blazing and glowing. They were placed on a large rock.
an6.62:13.11: Wouldn’t you know that those coals would not grow, increase, and spread?”
an6.62:13.13: “Or suppose it was the late afternoon and the sun was going down. Wouldn’t you know that the light was about to vanish and darkness appear?”
an6.62:13.15: “Or suppose that it’s nearly time for the midnight meal. Wouldn’t you know that the light had vanished and the darkness appeared?”
an6.62:13.17: “In the same way, when I’ve comprehended the mind of a person, I understand …
an6.62:13.22: This person is still liable to decline in the future …
an6.62:14.1: When I’ve comprehended the mind of a person, I understand:
an6.62:14.2: ‘Both wholesome and unwholesome qualities are found in this person.’
an6.62:14.3: After some time I comprehend their mind and understand:
an6.62:14.4: ‘The unwholesome qualities of this person have vanished, but the wholesome qualities are still present.
an6.62:14.5: Nevertheless, their wholesome root is unbroken, but it’s about to be totally destroyed.
an6.62:14.6: So this person is not liable to decline in the future.’
an6.62:14.7: Suppose that there were some burning coals, blazing and glowing. They were placed on a pile of grass or timber.
an6.62:14.8: Wouldn’t you know that those coals would grow, increase, and spread?”
an6.62:14.10: “Suppose the night is fading and the sun is rising. Wouldn’t you know that the dark will vanish and the light appear?”
an6.62:14.12: “Or suppose that it’s nearly time for the midday meal. Wouldn’t you know that the dark had vanished and the light appeared?”
an6.62:14.14: “In the same way, when I’ve comprehended the mind of a person, I understand …
an6.62:14.19: This person is not liable to decline in the future …
an6.62:15.1: When I’ve comprehended the mind of a person, I understand:
an6.62:15.2: ‘Both wholesome and unwholesome qualities are found in this person.’
an6.62:15.3: After some time I comprehend their mind and understand:
an6.62:15.4: ‘This person has not even a fraction of a hair’s tip of unwholesome qualities. They have exclusively bright, blameless qualities. They will become extinguished in this very life.’
an6.62:15.5: Suppose that there were some cool, extinguished coals. They were placed on a pile of grass or timber.
an6.62:15.6: Wouldn’t you know that those coals would not grow, increase, and spread?”
an6.62:15.8: “In the same way, when I’ve comprehended the mind of a person, I understand …
an6.62:15.11: ‘This person has not even a fraction of a hair’s tip of unwholesome qualities. They have exclusively bright, blameless qualities. They will become extinguished in this very life.’
an6.62:15.12: This is how another individual is known to the Realized One by comprehending their mind.
an6.62:15.13: And this is how the Realized One knows a person’s faculties by comprehending their mind.
an6.62:15.14: And this is how the Realized One knows the future origination of a person’s qualities by comprehending their mind.
an6.62:16.1: And so, Ānanda, of the first three people one is not liable to decline, one is liable to decline, and one is bound for a place of loss, hell.
an6.62:16.2: And of the second three people, one is liable to decline, one is not liable to decline, and one is bound to become extinguished.”
